newsitem.title: GERMANY: Rains damage E.German barley but will let up soon.
newsitem.headline: Rains damage E.German barley but will let up soon.

text.p: Excessive rainfall has disrupted the eastern German barley harvest but drier conditions are expected for next week, a source at the meteorological office DWD said.
"Rain has caused lodging which causes quality and volume losses as well as additional drying costs," he said.
"But the weather is drier in the west and should be a lot better across the country next week."
The problems applied to the winter barley, triticale and rye crops, mostly in the east and the south east of Germany.
Wheat, spring grains and oats still have a few weeks left before harvesting, but fears the rains could have affected wheat in some regions supported prices, traders said.
Harvesting of potatoes and rapeseed was also hampered because farmers were often unable to drive on soaked soils.
The rains washed away nutrients and caused some erosion.
Eastern German barley yields varied widely between four and nine four tonnes per hectare (tph), compared with the 1997 pan-German average 5.61 tph, farm price office ZMP reported.
Rapeseed yields in the region were betweeen three and four tph compared with the extremely low pan-German result of 2.28 tph last year. --Vera Eckert, Hamburg newsroom, +49-40-41903275
